title: Global Climate Crisis Deepens: Record CO2 Levels and Weakening Natural Carbon Sinks
topic: Record CO2 levels in 2024, extreme wildfires, and natural carbon sinks weakening globally.
story:
The Earth's atmosphere saw a record surge in carbon dioxide levels in 2024, reaching an alarming 424 parts per million (ppm). This increase of 3.5 ppm is the largest annual leap since modern measurements began in 1957, according to data from the UN and the World Meteorological Organization. Scientists express significant concern that the planet's natural carbon sinks – its lands and oceans – are losing their ability to absorb CO2 due to ongoing global heating, potentially creating a dangerous feedback loop that could accelerate temperature increases.

Contributing to this crisis, carbon emissions from extreme wildfires increased by 9% last year, marking the sixth highest level on record. Catastrophic fires in 2024 devastated vast areas, including 44.2 million acres in the Amazon, a 66% increase from 2023. Intense, fast-spreading blazes also ravaged South America's Pantanal wetlands and Chiquitano dry forest along the Bolivia-Brazil border, as well as northern forests in Canada. These events highlight the growing frequency and intensity of wildfires fueled by climate breakdown.

Further compounding the issue, new research published in Nature reveals that Australian tropical rainforest trees in Queensland have transitioned from being carbon sinks to net emitters of carbon from their trunks and branches. This shift, which began approximately 25 years ago, is attributed to increasingly extreme temperatures and drier conditions. While tropical forests are generally considered crucial carbon absorbers, this data, collected over nearly 50 years, suggests that their capacity is being undermined in vulnerable regions.

Even the world's oceans are showing signs of stress. A study based on chlorophyll concentrations from 2001 to 2023 indicates a loss of 'greenness' in low- to mid-latitude oceans. This decline is due to a reduction in phytoplankton, microscopic marine organisms responsible for nearly half of the biosphere's productivity and a vital component in oceanic carbon absorption. The weakening of this critical marine carbon sink has dire implications not only for CO2 absorption but also for global oxygen levels and marine food chains, further underscoring a planet struggling under the weight of climate change.
